title: Homeric Hymns To Selene 1-2
body: example of a god figuring as the primary hymnic subject nevertheless as secondary to Zeus, in the context of analyzing Zeus as the ultimate hymnic subject

title: Homeric Hymns To Selene 14-15
body: example of a god figuring as the primary hymnic subject nevertheless as secondary to Zeus, in the context of analyzing Zeus as the ultimate hymnic subject

title: Homeric Hymns To Selene 17-20
body: metabasis as signalling a shift from hymnic subject to epic subject (while the entire sequence of subjects remains technically a humnos)

title: Homeric Hymns To Selene 17-20
body: comparison of the hymnic prooimion that leads to the epic of the Wooden Horse in O.08 with the hymnic prooimia in Homeric Hymns, in the context of the analysis of the correlation of Apollo and the Muses with Zeus as transcendent hymnic subjects

title: Homeric Hymns To Selene 17-20
body: example of a god figuring as the primary hymnic subject nevertheless as secondary to Zeus, in the context of analyzing Zeus as the ultimate hymnic subject

title: Homeric Hymns To Selene 17-20
body: example of explicit statement of the new subject following a metabasis

title: Homeric Hymns To Selene 18-19
body: analysis of the klea (andrōn) and hēmitheōn (in the context of analyzing Iliad 9.524-525)

title: Homeric Hymns To Selene 18
body: analysis of humnos as introducing an epic narrative (kleos, erga/ergmata of heroes) after metabasis

title: Homeric Hymns To Selene 19
body: analysis of humnos as introducing an epic narrative (kleos, erga/ergmata of heroes) after metabasis

title: Homeric Hymns To Selene 19

title: Homeric Hymns To Selene 19
body: analysis of kleos (and derivatives) as denoting the act of praising
